Tim Walz’s stay-at-home order","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"link","attrs":{"href":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/25/latest-on-covid19-in-minnesota","title":null,"className":null}}]},{"text":", intended to slow the spread of COVID-19 across the state and tamp down its impacts, is a dramatic step that requires people to stay home unless absolutely necessary.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"It’s a far-reaching measure that has the potential to drastically impact the lives of all Minnesotans, changing the ways in which we work, play, learn and go about our daily lives.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"apm_related_list","attrs":{"title":""},"content":[{"type":"apm_related_link","attrs":{"url":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/25/latest-on-covid19-in-minnesota","title":"Walz issues 'stay at home' order to combat coronavirus","prefix":"The latest","content_id":null,"content_type":null,"custom_class":"default"}},{"type":"apm_related_link","attrs":{"url":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/25/walz-emergency-orders-have-some-questioning-whether-he-has-too-much-power","title":"Walz emergency orders leave some questioning","prefix":"Too much power?","content_id":null,"content_type":null,"custom_class":"default"}},{"type":"apm_related_link","attrs":{"url":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/25/legislative-leaders-react-to-walz-stay-at-home-order","title":"After Walz issues order","prefix":"Legislative leaders react","content_id":null,"content_type":null,"custom_class":"default"}}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"But what will it mean, in practical terms?","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"If you have a question about how this will impact your life, ","type":"text"},{"text":"please share it with us","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"link","attrs":{"href":"https://modules.wearehearken.com/mpr/embed/5043/share","title":"","className":"default"}}]},{"text":". Stay safe.\"","preferred_aspect_ratio_slug":"uncropped"}},{"type":"heading","attrs":{"level":2,"anchor":null},"content":[{"text":"When does the stay-at-home order go into effect?","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"The order goes into effect at 11:59 p.m. on Friday, March 27. It is set to last until Friday, April 10 at 5 p.m.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"heading","attrs":{"level":2,"anchor":null},"content":[{"text":"So, what am I still allowed to do?","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Lots of things. Minnesotans are allowed to do several things outside their homes — as long as they follow social distancing recommendations. ","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Get “necessary supplies and services.”","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":" If you need something, you can go get it. This includes food (groceries, delivery or carry-out), beverages (including alcohol; liquor stores are not closed under the order), gas, supplies that will help you work from home, and products you need to clean and maintain homes, vehicles, bicycles and businesses. State officials ask residents to use their best judgment and purchase only what they need. You can also leave to do your laundry!","type":"text"}]},{"type":"apm_image","attrs":{"id":"e807573caf7f7f70ae60e2c0e12130caae94fa1d","url":"https://img.publicradio.org/images/20200325-covid-liquor.jpg","type":"apmImage","float":"none","width":"full","credit":"Christine T. dn.org/e807573caf7f7f70ae60e2c0e12130caae94fa1d/widescreen/b24abc-20200325-covid-liquor.jpg","width":2000,"height":1123}]}},"short_caption":"A ","preferred_aspect_ratio_slug":"uncropped"}},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Get medical care.","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":" If you need emergency medical services, of course you’re allowed to leave your home. You can also go if you need other medical services, supplies, or medications — or to visit a health care or dental professional or facility. You can also leave to visit a veterinarian. And you may leave to donate blood.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"apm_related_list","attrs":{"title":""},"content":[{"type":"apm_related_link","attrs":{"url":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/25/latest-on-covid19-in-minnesota","title":"Walz issues 'stay at home' order to curb coronavirus","prefix":"Wednesday","content_id":null,"content_type":null,"custom_class":"default"}},{"type":"apm_related_link","attrs":{"url":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/20/coronavirus-forces-pregnant-women-to-change-birth-plans","title":"Coronavirus forces pregnant women to change birth plans","prefix":"Uncertainty, stress","content_id":null,"content_type":null,"custom_class":"default"}}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Care for others.","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":" You may leave to care for a family member, friend or pet in another household, or to provide transportation for them. The order specifically identifies “existing parenting time schedules or other visitation schedules pertaining to a child in need of protective services” as acceptable reasons for leaving home under the order.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Get out of an unsafe situation. ","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":"You may also move to another residence if your home becomes unsafe, or if you’re in an unsafe situation — the governor’s order specifically referenced those “who have suffered or are at risk of domestic violence.” ","type":"text"}]},{"type":"apm_image","attrs":{"id":"1891586e84a47a1cb99b5ccd5e283e6d17a70888","url":"https://img.publicradio.org/images/20200310-rice-shortage-02.jpg","type":"apmImage","float":"none","width":"full","credit":"Christine T. ","preferred_aspect_ratio_slug":"uncropped"}},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"People without a home are exempt from the restrictions in the governor’s order, and are allowed to move among emergency shelter, drop-in centers and encampments. The order also specifically forbids “sweeps or disbandment” of homeless encampments, saying that they would exacerbate the potential spread of the coronavirus. ","type":"text"},{"type":"hard_break"},{"type":"hard_break"},{"text":"Get home. ","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":"The order also allows people to travel within the state and out of state for allowed activities — and to return home.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Take a drive.","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":" The order says people are allowed to “drive for pleasure,” and may go to public parks and other public places that are open, as long as they maintain safe social distancing.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Travel within or between tribal lands.","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"strong"}]},{"text":" Minnesota’s Native American reservations, federal trust lands and activities on the state’s treaty territories are exempt from the restrictions in Walz’s order. Several Native nations have already put in place their own restrictions. See above for more details.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"It’s worth noting that before the “stay at home” order was issued, many resort owners in northern Minnesota had already made the tough decision to ","type":"text"},{"text":"cancel cabin reservations","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"link","attrs":{"href":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/21/coronavirus-spread-in-minnesota-forces-north-shore-resort-owners-to-make-tough-decisions","title":null,"className":null}}]},{"text":".","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"And some local officials in northern Minnesota and Wisconsin are asking cabin and second home owners not to visit during the current outbreak.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"On March 24, the Cook County Board of Commissioners ","type":"text"},{"text":"unanimously approved a travel advisory","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"link","attrs":{"href":"https://www.mprnews.org/story/2020/03/24/cook-county-to-secondhome-owners-stay-away-for-now","title":null,"className":null}}]},{"text":" requesting that seasonal or second homeowners stay home — for the time being.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"“Due to our very limited health care infrastructure, please do not visit us now,” the county’s advisory reads.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Cook County lies at the tip of Minnesota's Arrowhead region and borders Canada, Lake Superior and the Boundary Waters; includes four state parks, the Gunflint Trail, Grand Portage National Monument; and the towns of Lutsen, Tofte and Grand Marais. Tourism makes up more than 80 percent of its economy.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"Commissioners took action after they heard from county residents about what they perceived to be an influx of visitors from the Twin Cities and elsewhere — opening up their seasonal homes and staying at local resorts during a time when state health officials are emphasizing the need for social distancing to tamp the spread of the coronavirus.","type":"text"}]},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"text":"The advisory is not mandatory — and it’s not legally enforceable. But county leaders are concerned that its limited health care infrastructure, grocery stores and other retailers aren’t equipped to handle additional visitors. advisory","type":"text","marks":[{"type":"link","attrs":{"href":"https://kbjr6.com/2020/03/22/bayfield-county-health-department-advises-seasonal-homeowners-to-stay-home/","title":null,"className":null}}]},{"text":"
